;津巴布韦警方表示，他们逮捕了 41 名投票监控组织的工作人员，并没收了电脑和其他物品星期四，在这个南部非洲国家广泛推迟的总统选举中，他们使用设备来统计计票结果。

;

;被捕者正在与两个经过认可的监测组织合作——津巴布韦选举支持网络和选举资源中心– 在全国部署了 7,500 多名观察员。警方发言人 Paul Nyathi 指责他们参与“颠覆和犯罪活动”，作为反对派捏造结果计划的一部分。

;

;“这些数据是由一些观察员和政党特工提供的，”Nyathi

;

;在突袭包括一家酒店在内的多个地点进行的逮捕行动受到津巴布韦人权律师组织的批评，该组织表示，这些工作人员正在履行作为认可选举观察员的任务。

;

; >;

;津巴布韦长期以来充满争议的选举历史让许多人对官方结果持谨慎态度。在著名研究机构 Afrobarometer 进行的一项选前调查中，近一半的受访者表示，他们担心“公布的结果不会反映统计结果。”

;

;80 岁的总统埃默森·姆南加古瓦 (Emmerson Mnangagwa) 寻求选举结果在许多地区投票延迟长达 10 个小时后，他利用总统权力将数十个投票站的投票延长至周四晚上。

;

;他的主要挑战者、45 岁的纳尔逊·查米萨 (Nelson Chamisa)一位在 2018 年有争议的选举中以微弱优势落败的老律师称这次投票是一场骗局，称推迟投票的目的是剥夺其城市据点选民的选举权。

;

;周三晚些时候，几小时后，选票仍在打印。投票应该已经结束了。其他投票站开始计票。一些沮丧的选民睡在首都哈拉雷的投票站，依偎在毯子下或生火取暖。

;

;津巴布韦的高风险投票在因延误而受到影响的选区延长

;

;“我们在这里度过了一整夜，”穿着大衣的卡德韦尔·蒙乔马 (Cadwell Munjoma) 说道，他在中产阶级梅贝尔雷恩 (Mabelreign) 郊区的一个投票站投票。 “这是我一生中第一次看到人们因为没有文件而无法投票的情况。这没有道理。”

;

;反对派和各个民间团体表示，他们将独立编制计票结果，并在计票后张贴在投票站外。

;

;姆南加古瓦称津巴布韦为“大师” ”，并批评几周前对投票可信度表示担忧的西方国家。

;

;在哈拉雷和其他城市地区的许多投票站，人们在被告知后向选举官员和警察推搡和大喊大叫。选票已经用完。国营先驱报援引司法部长 Ziyambi Ziyambi 的话说，选票的印刷工作将于周三深夜完成。

;

;一些投票站在官方关闭时间两小时后开放，而其他投票站则暂停投票官员们要求人们早上返回。

;

;一些等待的选民用塑料桶洗脸。其他人则紧盯着手机，敦促晚上回家的邻居和家人返回并准备投票。

;

;津巴布韦选举委员会承认一些投票站选票分发较晚，并指责它是关于“由于众多法庭挑战而导致的”印刷延迟。执政党活动人士和反对派就谁可以参加总统和议会选举提出了一系列诉讼。

;

;这是自长期统治者罗伯特·穆加贝在政变中被推翻以来的第二次大选。 2017 年。

;

;这个拥有 1500 万人口的南部非洲国家拥有丰富的矿产资源，其中包括非洲最大的锂储量，锂是制造电动汽车电池的关键成分。但监管机构长期以来一直声称，普遍存在的腐败和管理不善已经削弱了该国的大部分潜力。

;

;选举前，包括人权观察和国际特赦组织在内的反对派和人权组织指责姆南加古瓦在不断上升的局势中试图压制异见。货币危机、食品价格大幅上涨、公共卫生系统薄弱以及缺乏正式就业机会导致紧张局势。

;

;姆南加古瓦是穆加贝的亲密盟友，并在未来的后果发生之前担任副总统2017 年政变。他试图将自己描绘成一名改革者，但许多人指责他更具压制性。

;

;过去二十年来，津巴布韦因侵犯人权的指控而受到美国和欧盟的制裁。遭到执政党的否认。姆南加古瓦重复了穆加贝针对西方的大部分言论，指责西方试图推翻他的政权。

;去年年底，无助的帝企鹅幼崽在南极洲西部的多个繁殖地溺水身亡科学家周四表示，当全球变暖侵蚀的海冰在它们的小脚下融化时，它们就会被冻死。

;

;在别林斯高晋海地区监测的五个地点中，除了一个地点外，所有地点的雏鸟都经历了 100% 的损失”，他们在《自然》杂志《通讯：地球与环境》上报道。

;

;他们称之为“灾难性的繁殖失败”。

;

;“这是全世界帝企鹅首次重大繁殖失败。英国南极调查局研究员彼得·弗雷特韦尔（Peter Fretwell）说：“由于海冰消失，出现了一些殖民地，这可能是即将发生的事情的一个征兆。”

;

;“我们已经预测这一情况有一段时间了，但实际上看到这种情况的发生是严峻的。”

;

;去年南半球春季（从九月中旬到十二月中旬）南大洋的海冰数量创下历史新低，特别是在南极洲西海岸半岛是世界上最大企鹅物种的主要繁殖地。

;

;陆地附近开阔水域上形成的冰过早破裂，对数千只尚未成熟到足以应对寒冷海洋的幼企鹅来说是致命的

;

;一只小帝企鹅从雄性企鹅在冬天保暖的蛋中诞生，而繁殖对中的雌性则开始了为期两个月的捕鱼探险。返回巢穴后，她通过反刍喂养雏鸟。

;

;为了独立生存，雏鸟必须长出防水羽毛，这一过程称为长羽，通常在 12 月中旬开始，持续几周。

;

;但是别林斯高晋海殖民地的冰在去年 11 月底开始融化。

;

;“冰会破裂、瓦解或碎成浮冰，然后飘走，”弗雷特韦尔解释道.

;

;“进入水中的小鸡很可能会被淹死，但即使它们设法爬出来，它们也可能会被冻死，”他补充道。

;

;“如果它们成功了，它们就会被冻死。”为了留在冰山上，我们假设它们中的大多数会漂流并挨饿，因为父母无法找到它们。”

;

;众所周知，帝企鹅会寻找替代地点以应对不稳定的海冰，但南极洲气候变化的加速影响可能会超过它们的适应能力。

;

;“如果繁殖栖息地在区域层面变得不稳定，这样的策略将不可能实现，”该研究得出结论。

; >;

;与地球另一端的北极熊一样，主要由燃烧化石燃料引起的全球变暖是威胁标志性帝企鹅长期生存的唯一因素。

;

;中国科学家说企鹅在极地冰盖之前就停止飞行

;

;其他面临灭绝的大型动物主要受到栖息地丧失和过度开发的威胁。

;

;帝企鹅，又名 Aptenodytes forsteri，数量约四分之一根据 2020 年的一项研究，有 100 万对繁殖对，全部在南极洲。

;

;别林斯高晋海的栖息地占总数的不到 5%。

;

;“但总体而言，大约 30 Fretwell 说：“去年 % 的种群受到海冰消失的影响，因此将会有更多的雏鸟无法生存。”

;

;2 月中旬，南极洲的海冰范围缩小至 200 万平方公里（近 800,000 平方英里），比 1981-2010 年平均水平低约 30%。

;

;G20 在 2022 年在化石燃料上花费了创纪录的 1.4 万亿美元：报告

;

;覆盖的五个殖民地该研究指出的罗斯柴尔德岛、威尔第湾、斯麦莱特岛、布莱恩半岛和普弗罗格纳角都是在过去 14 年里通过中分辨率卫星图像发现的，并且使用高分辨率图像计算了它们的数量。

;

;由于企鹅粪便或鸟粪具有独特的粉棕色色调，在企鹅居住的九个月内，这些粪便覆盖了广阔的区域，因此从太空中可以看到这些殖民地，即使这些殖民地本身并不总是可见。 p>;

;只有罗斯柴尔德岛被科学家访问过，其他地点中只有斯麦莱特岛被航空观测到过。

;

;雄性和雌性帝企鹅的羽毛和大小相似，达到了身高一米，重达 20 公斤。

;

;在隆冬，它们挤在一起抵御风寒，轮流用自己的身体作为盾牌。

;

;研究结果支持了预测在当前的全球变暖轨迹下，到本世纪末，该物种的 90% 将“准灭绝”。

;

;美国进口禁令实施一年后，中国棉花种植面积减少新疆维吾尔自治区，由于质量推动和粮食安全推动，预计今年产量将大幅下降。

;

;中国提供了世界 20% 以上的棉花，主要来自西部新疆地区据分析师和农民称，由于注重质量而非数量，并为农作物腾出空间，其产量可能会下降 10% 以上。

;

;过去几个月也可能出现气候冲击导致该地区产量下降，在美国领导的抵制所谓强迫劳动的事件之后，该地区的产品正被转移到中国“一带一路”倡议的一部分国家。北京一直否认这些指控。

;

;美国于2022年6月生效的《维吾尔族强迫劳动预防法》实际上阻止了美国进口全部或部分源自新疆的所有产品。

;

;“多年来，政府一直致力于棉花产业的高质量发展，去年取得了明显进展，认为不适合棉花生长的田地改种了其他作物，”一位人士表示。北京棉花展望咨询公司的声明。

;

;她预计2023年新疆产量将比去年下降11%至557万吨，而中国总产量预计将比2022年下降11.8%至557万吨。 598 万吨。

;

;庞大的新疆生产建设兵团 7 月份发布的一项指示称，其 16 个部门将在年底前停止种植棉花，以“优先安排种植结构，提高质量” .

;

;在粮食安全推动下，关键谷物削减了中国丰富的棉花产量

;

;“过去我们可以在所有 8,000 亩（1,320 英亩）土地上种植棉花，但现在这是不允许的。”在南疆铁门关经营农民合作社的金穗峰说。

;

;“现在有 2000 到 3000 亩土地被用来种植粮食作物，尽管棉花显然比棉花更重要。 ”

;

;北疆和布克赛尔县一家合作社的负责人张文军说，去年该乡棉田有8.7万亩，今年减少了1万亩。

;

;“现在，当局鼓励我们种植谷物，而不是棉花，”他说。

;

;由于对粮食的担忧，北京近年来加大了粮食生产力度棉花种植面积的减少也符合全球趋势，因为成本增加和产量下降后，农民选择减少种植。北京棉花展望咨询补充称，去年价格降低了利润。

;

;国联期货农业分析师徐亚光预计，新疆棉花播种面积可能下降8.5%，单产可能下降8.5%。 5%。

;

;春季的大风大雨和过去一个月的长达一个月的热浪等极端天气可能会导致新疆部分地区的产量下降。

;

;

;“最终的产出结果将取决于未来几周的天气，”徐说。

;

;北京棉花展望咨询公司指出，7月份中国零售额出现今年迄今为止最大跌幅，但作为行业景气指标的纺纱工厂开工率仍然相当高。

;

;出口方面，中国 7 月份纺织品和服装发货量也大幅下降，该咨询公司将其归因于欧洲和北美需求疲软，而欧洲和北美是中国棉花产品的传统目的地。

;

;“这些地区的服装公司他们补充说，在新疆棉花禁令之前，一些地区已经储备了中国商品，因此供应并不短缺，但销售仍然低迷。

;

;随着欧洲和北美青睐印度和越南等国家，她说，中国的应对措施是专注于国内市场，同时也将出口转向“一带一路”倡议成员。

;

;“因此，对中国棉花的需求不太可能增加，但也不会太多。 ”她说。

;

;中国国内市场每年消耗800万吨棉花，这意味着它还需要进口来补充供应。

;

;“欧洲北美曾经是我们高端纱线的主要市场，但现在转向国内工厂或者中东、非洲的工厂，在那里以较低的价格出售。因此利润越来越小。”铁门关农民金说。

;

;

;近年来，由于德黑兰经济增长缓慢，伊朗经济陷入困境，中国增加了与拥有世界第二大天然气储量的伊朗的贸易

;

; Thu, 24 Aug 2023 22:50:02 +0800 Oldest US-China science deal hangs in the balance as Washington seeks to ‘amend terms’https://www.scmp.com/news/china/science/article/3232207/oldest-us-china-science-deal-hangs-balance-washington-seeks-amend-terms?utm_source=rss_feed

;允许具有里程碑意义的美中科学研究协议失效对双方来说都是损失观察人士称，华盛顿寻求将这项已有数十年历史的协议延长六个月，该协议将在几天内续签。

;

;1979 年的《科学技术协议》是美中关系建立后签署的第一项协议当年实现正常化。该协议将于周日到期，无需采取行政行动来维持其效力。

;

;短期延期将使 STA 保持有效，因为美国寻求“有权进行谈判以修改和加强[其]条款”， Reuters cited a US State Department spokesman as saying on Wednesday.

;

;However, this “does not commit the United States to a longer-term extension”, the spokesperson was quoted as saying.

;

;Signed by then US president Jimmy Carter and Chinese paramount leader Deng Xiaoping, the STA has so far been renewed about every five years, serving as an “umbrella agreement” for bilateral scientific and technological cooperation.

;

;A Beijing -based science policy expert, who requested anonymity due to the sensitivity of the issue, said the Chinese scientific community would like to see the agreement renewed.

;

;The STA had benefited both countries, the expert said. “China and the US have been cooperating in science and technology for more than 40 years and China has benefited a lot. The cooperation enhanced China's overall scientific research level and its international research status.”

;

;The uncertainty over the deal comes as the US seeks to reset China ties following some of their worst tensions in recent years – over issues including trade, human rights and hi-tech rivalry – while protecting national security.

;

;Pang Zhongying, a chair professor in international political economy at Sichuan University in southeastern China, said the US intention to extend the agreement was “good news”.

;

;“[This is because] the US has demonstrated they are willing to improve the bilateral relationship or maintain it,” Pang said, but conceded that there was still a great deal of uncertainty about the future of the STA.

;

;He said that as the world's top two economies, the US and China were both pivotal to global science and technology and should be interdependent in the sector.

;

;“I hope the relevant departments in China and the US can negotiate actively because a termination of the agreement would be a loss for both countries.”

;

;The US State Department's short-term extension plan comes after a number of US lawmakers opposed the renewal of the 44-year-old deal, expressing concerns about China exploiting the collaboration to advance its military modernisation goals.

;

;In a letter to US Secretary of State Antony Blinken in June, 10 Republican members of Congress said evidence suggested that China would “continue to look for opportunities to exploit partnerships organised under the STA to advance its military objectives to the greatest extent possible and, in some cases, to attempt to undermine American sovereignty”.

;

;Clock ticks down for China-US science deal amid tech theft fears

;

;However, some American scientists have argued that failure to renew the agreement would “directly and negatively” affect the US' own research.

;

;In an open letter to US President Joe Biden and National Security Council members on Monday, two Stanford University professors said the STA had been of “enormous benefit” to the US, and that the nation should renew the accord because it was in its best interest.

;

;“We can attest that cutting off ties with China would directly and negatively impact our own research, the work of our immediate colleagues, and/or the educational mission of our universities,” Steven Kivelson and Peter Michelson wrote in the letter.

;

;Deborah Seligsohn, a senior associate at the Centre for Strategic and International Studies, a Washington think tank, also said the US should extend the STA because “it is in the United States' clear self-interest to do so”.

;

;The agreement had yielded many outcomes that had deeply benefited the US and the rest of the world, including cooperation on the study of birth defects, influenza, HIV/Aids prevention and tackling air pollution, Seligsohn wrote on the CSIS website earlier this month.

;

;“American and Chinese scientists have worked together through almost 100 protocols and annexes under the agreement,” she wrote.

;

;“The umbrella … agreement is the specific prerequisite for government-to-government cooperation.”

;

;China has expressed its willingness to renew the accord, with Chinese embassy spokesman Liu Pengyu saying in Washington in June that the US had been approached a year ago to discuss the renewal.

;

;“As far as we know, the US side is still conducting an internal review on the renewal of the agreement,” Liu had said. “It is hoped that the US side will expedite the internal review before the expiration of the agreement.”

;UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak should have declared his wife's stake in a company that was set to benefit from government cash, a parliamentary watchdog declared on Thursday.

;

;Sunak vowed “integrity, professionalism and accountability at every level” when he came to power, after the short-lived tenure of Liz Truss and the scandal-hit premiership of Boris Johnson.

;

;But in a year in office, he has received a police fine for not wearing a seat belt, on top of another for breaking Covid lockdown rules when he was finance minister under Johnson.

;

;House of Commons Standards Commissioner Daniel Greenberg began a probe in April after receiving a complaint about Sunak's comments to a committee of senior MPs the previous month.

;

;Sunak failed to mention to them and in a follow-up letter that his wife, Akshata Murty, held shares in a child-minding firm that would receive additional state funding.

;

;He told Greenberg he had been advised that Murty's shareholding “did not meet the test of relevance to require publication on the List of Minister's Interests”.

;

;But the commissioner disagreed, saying that it “was a relevant interest that should have been declared” and he had “a duty to correct the record”.

;

;The omission may have arisen out of confusion about what was required and was “inadvertent”, he concluded.

;

;The prime minister's spokesman said the matter had been resolved. “The prime minister takes seriously his responsibilities to register and declare all relevant interests,” he added.

;

;During his time at the Treasury Sunak was criticised after it emerged that Murty, whose father co-founded Indian IT giant Infosys, had so-called “non-dom” status.

;

;UK PM, Saudi crown prince meeting criticised after killing of journalist

;

;That meant she did not declare earnings from her dividends in the firm for UK tax purposes. After a furore, Murty later said she would include them.

;

;Critics, including the main opposition Labour Party, have said Sunak, a wealthy former investment banker, is out of touch with ordinary voters struggling with rising costs.

;Prices of luxury homes in Dubai shot up 48.8 per cent year on year and 11.6 per cent quarter on quarter as of June 30, putting the wealthy United Arab Emirates (UAE) city on top of a global ranking for the eighth straight quarter, while Hong Kong fell to 35th spot.

;

;Tokyo occupies the second spot on the list, compiled by property consultancy Knight Frank, with a 26.2 per cent increase, followed by the Philippine capital of Manila with a 19.9 per cent jump.

;

;Hong Kong's “prime” homes – defined by Knight Frank as the top 5 per cent of the residential market in terms of value – lost 1.5 per cent of their value for the year. In the second quarter, prime prices fell 0.4 per cent from the previous three-month period, Knight Frank said, pushing the city down one spot in the quarterly ranking, which tracks 46 cities around the world.

;

;“Global housing markets are still under pressure from the shift to higher interest rates,” said Liam Bailey, Knight Frank's global head of research. “But the latest results … confirm that prices are being supported by strong underlying demand, weak supply following disruption to new-build projects during the pandemic and an ongoing return of workers to cities.”

;

;For the entire year, Dubai is likely to see an overall 14 per cent increase in prime property prices, Knight Frank said.

;

;“Remarkably, prices in Dubai have soared by 225 per cent since reaching a pandemic low in the third quarter of 2020,” the report said.

;

;“The city has evolved from a regional to a global hub over the past five years,” Bailey said previously. “Pre-pandemic the city was of significant importance to the Middle East region, but this importance has grown in terms of business links to India, Asia, Europe and even the US.”

;

;Mortgages on unfinished homes in Hong Kong fall to 17-year low amid rising rates

;

;A study by Savills, released earlier this month, named Dubai the most favoured destination for so-called executive nomads, typically business owners or those holding senior executive positions.

;

;In the Savills study, which ranked 20 cities, Dubai scored high in terms of quality of life and connectivity, as its main airport “is now the world's busiest for international passenger traffic” and the UAE is “home to the fastest mobile internet speeds in the world”.

;

;Meanwhile, Hong Kong's property market has been struggling. In addition to high interest rates, a recent surge in unsold inventory from newly developed projects weighed on prime property prices in Hong Kong, Knight Frank said.

;

;K Wah's profit falls by more than half amid Hong Kong's higher interest rates

;

;“To stimulate demand, the city has tweaked its financing regulations, raising the mortgage loan-to-value ratio to 70 per cent for residential properties valued at HK$15 million [US$1.9 million] or less,” the report said. “While this change will likely be welcomed by buyers, its ability to significantly boost growth remains uncertain.”

;

;Globally, the Knight Frank report suggests an improving outlook, according to Bailey.

;

;“As uncertainty over the direction of inflation appears to have reduced in recent months, price adjustments in many markets are likely to be less pronounced than was expected even three months ago,” he said.

;Taiwan will increase its defence spending to a record NT$606.8 billion (US$19 billion) next year to tackle growing challenges from the People's Liberation Army.

;

;The spending – approved by the self-ruled island's cabinet on Thursday – is up 4.6 per cent from 2023, Premier Chen Chien-jen told reporters in Taipei after a meeting on the government's budget for next year.

;

;It comes after the Pentagon gave the green light for the sale to Taiwan of advanced sensor systems for F-16 fighter jets worth US$500 million, and as the PLA ramped up pressure on Taipei with live-fire drills off the coast of Fujian – the mainland Chinese province closest to the island.

;

;The defence budget – comprising NT$440.6 billion for the military, NT$94.3 billion for “special” expenditure, and NT$71.9 billion in supplementary funds – still needs final approval from the legislature.

;

;“It accounts for 15 per cent of the spending,” Chen said, referring to the military portion in the overall budget of NT$2.88 trillion for next year.

;

;Much of the spending will go towards improving the island's defences against increasing threats from the PLA, which has rapidly expanded its presence in the Taiwan Strait and the region in recent years, according to Taiwanese military officials.

;

;That includes NT$130.6 billion to develop new weapons, up NT$33.6 billion from 2023; NT$131 billion for operational maintenance costs, down NT$2.6 billion from this year; and NT$179 billion for personnel and training, an increase of NT$400 million.

;

;Of the special funds, NT$45.3 billion will be used to buy new-generation warplanes from abroad, while NT$49 billion will finance a programme to improve the island's air force and navy.

;

;Taiwan withdraws from Parlacen after vote in favour of Beijing

;

;The defence budget amounts to around 2.5 per cent of Taiwan's GDP, and marks a 38 per cent increase compared to the military spending when President Tsai Ing-wen took office in 2016.

;

;But compared to Beijing's military spending “there is still a lot of room to grow”, according to Su Tzu-yun, a senior analyst at the Institute for National Defence and Security Research, a government think tank in Taipei.

;

;In March, Beijing announced a 7.2 per cent increase in its defence budget to 1.55 trillion yuan (US$214.5 billion) for this year – the fastest growth since 2019 – amid rising tensions with the US over a range of issues including Taiwan.

;

;Beijing views Taiwan as part of its territory and has not renounced the use of force to bring the island under its control. The PLA has intensified its sabre-rattling near Taiwan in recent years in a warning to pro-independence forces and as the island moves closer to Washington.

;

;The United States, like most countries, does not recognise Taiwan as an independent state but is opposed to any unilateral change in the cross-strait status quo by force.

;

;Su said that while Taiwan's military budget could not be expected to catch up to Beijing's, the authorities needed to steadily increase spending to maintain the island's defence capabilities.

;

;“It would be reasonable to increase it to US$25 billion, which would be about 3 per cent of GDP,” he said.

;

;Chieh Chung, a security researcher at the National Policy Foundation, a think tank affiliated with the main opposition Kuomintang party in Taipei, noted that the defence ministry would have a “huge” weapons bill next year.

;

;“This explains why there will be a record increase in its spending,” he said.

;

;But he noted that NT$2.6 billion had been cut from operational costs for next year, while funds for personnel and training had increased by just NT$400 million.

;

;“We may get a number of new weapons, but not adequate funds to keep them in good operational status,” Chieh said.

;

;And with the island resuming the mandatory 12 months of military service from next year, it was not clear whether the funding earmarked for personnel and training would be enough to cover the influx of conscripts, according to Chieh.

;

;At least 9,100 Taiwanese are expected to be conscripted into the military for a year in 2024. It is an extension of the current four months of training, with the aim of improving the standard of the island's troops so they can take on the PLA in the event of a cross-strait conflict.
